dt: {bc}serving to {d_link|dismiss|dismiss} or reject someone or something {bc}having or showing a disdainful attitude toward someone or something regarded as unworthy of serious attention

dt.t: He responded to the question with a {wi}dismissive{/wi} wave.
In the past, Westerberg had been {wi}dismissive{/wi} of Bob's playing, but he says relistening to the early records gave him a new perspective.

utxt.t: Writer Tom Fontana's violent, realistic drama debuted five years ago and uninitiated viewers still {wi}dismissively{/wi} call it "that prison show on HBO."
These are not people who speak {wi}dismissively{/wi} of the brain's capabilities.
The work of feminist scholars, both individually and collectively, has been greeted in some quarters with impatience, irritation, {wi}dismissiveness{/wi}, even contempt.

shortdef: serving to dismiss or reject someone or something : having or showing a disdainful attitude toward someone or something regarded as unworthy of serious attention
